arch:property.oc:show_val: South West Portion of Suspended Floor Subflooring, West of Locus 15

A preserved section of the subflooring used to support the Suspended Floor in the Hypocaust Chamber. As a result of the impact from the collapse event, especially from the toppled superstructure from the South Wall (Locus 2), this section of the subflooring has slumped to a level slightly lower than the area still in situ beneath the extant Suspended Floor (Locus 13), and its counterpart Locus 11B to the east. While the area beneath this subflooring locus remains unexcavated, visual inspection of the substructure suggests that the slumping resulted specifically from the compaction and disintegration of a portion of the terracotta tiles used in its construction. The subflooring stratum itself consists of 4-5 alternating layers of terracotta floor tiles and a thick gray mortar. The top surface is a thick layer of the mortar, which served as the bedding for the limestone pavers still extant. The substructure underlying this area of the subflooring stratum consists of multiple layers and rows of square terracotta tiles, approximately 3-4 cm each in height, tightly laid with thin layers of wet-mortar. The result of this construction is a nearly solid bastion-like foundation for the Suspended Floor, akin to those at the east end of the chamber (Locus 32) beneath the Locus 11B Subflooring.
South side of Tr. 126, west of Blocked Door Locus 15.

Phase VI: Late Nabataean pre-CE 106 minor collapses and repairs. At this time the northwest subterranean channel is damaged and clogged with CE 1st c. pottery. Repairs are made to the Hexagonal Pavement as well as to the East Exedra walls. Bath Complex built.
1.10 m north south-by-1.70 m east west.
